Weapon Attack.description: You are embarassed by your poor showing, but nothing remarkable happens.
Weapon Attack.lore: Bards sing mournfully of Duelmaster Jorra’s attempt to shouted the wrong incantation at a critical moment.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your combat footing, exposing yourself to your target.
Weapon Attack.effect: Your target has advantage on their first attack roll against you next round.
Weapon Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Sir Galwyn, who famously fell into a decorative fountain while charging.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your combat footing, exposing yourself to your enemies.
Weapon Attack.effect: Your enemies have advantage on their first attack roll against you next round.
Weapon Attack.lore: The archives of Thalem record a similar blunder during the Great Summit.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your combat footing, and have difficulty recovering.
Weapon Attack.effect: Your enemies have advantage on their attack rolls against you until the end of your next turn.
Weapon Attack.lore: It is said that during the the Battle of Shifting Sands, Lady Myri tripped over her own weapon.

Weapon Attack.description: Melee: You get tangled with your enemy and fall over. Ranged: You spill your quiver.
Weapon Attack.effect: Melee: You are knocked prone and your movement is reduced to 0. Your target must succeed a DC 10 dexterity check or they are also knocked prone. Ranged: You must pick up arrows individually from the ground using your “environmental interaction,” or the “Use an Object” action to nock your bow.
Weapon Attack.lore: The archives of Stormwatch Keep record a similar blunder during the Great Summit.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your balance while attacking.
Weapon Attack.effect: You fall prone and your movement is reduced to 0.
Weapon Attack.lore: The archives of The Mistlands record a similar blunder during the Siege of Broken Hill.

Weapon Attack.description: As you attack your opponent you begin to fear that they are the superior combatant.
Weapon Attack.effect: Disadvantage on your next attack roll against your target.
Weapon Attack.lore: The archives of The Mistlands record a similar blunder during the Siege of Broken Hill.

Weapon Attack.description: You miss an attack and gaze upon the chaos of the battle, causing your confidence to falter.
Weapon Attack.effect: Disadvantage on your next attack roll against any target.
Weapon Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Sir Galwyn, who famously summoned a chicken instead of a fireball.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your grip as you attack.
Weapon Attack.effect: Roll a DC 10 Dexterity Check; on failure, you drop your weapon at your feet.
Weapon Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Apprentice Threx, who famously shouted the wrong incantation at a critical moment.

Weapon Attack.description: Melee: The weapon slips from your hand as you attack. Ranged: Your ammunition gets lodged in its container.
Weapon Attack.effect: Melee: Roll a DC 10 Dexterity Check; on failure, you throw your weapon into your enemy’s space. DM determines where the item is thrown on large sized or greater creatures. Ranged: You must use an action to organize the ammunition in its case before you can make another ranged attack.
Weapon Attack.lore: The archives of Stormwatch Keep record a similar blunder during the Festival of Lights.

Weapon Attack.description: Melee: You lunge past an enemy exposing yourself to his attack. Ranged: Your missile startles your allies near your target.
Weapon Attack.effect: Melee: Enemy you were attacking is able to use their reaction to perform and attack of opportunity. Ranged: the target can perform an opportunity attack on any ally within melee range.
Weapon Attack.lore: Legends from Silverdeep speak of the day a hero lost their footing before a duel.

Weapon Attack.description: Missing what you thought was a critical blow causes you to panic.
Weapon Attack.effect: End your current turn and you are surprised until the end of your next turn.
Weapon Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Arcanist Vorn, who famously tripped over their own weapon.

Weapon Attack.description: You attack wildly and lose track of the fight around you.
Weapon Attack.effect: End your turn and move to the bottom of the initiative order at the start of the next round.
Weapon Attack.lore: It is said that during the the Siege of Broken Hill, Velruun lost their footing before a duel.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your footing while attacking and fall to the ground bumping your head.
Weapon Attack.effect: You fall prone. Roll a DC 10 constitution save. On failure, you take 1d6 damage and are knocked unconscious for 1 minute or until you receive damage from any source. On success, take half damage and you remain conscious.
Weapon Attack.lore: It is said that during the the Siege of Broken Hill, Duelmaster Jorra froze mid-spell, overcome by sneezing.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your footing while attacking and fall head first.
Weapon Attack.effect: You fall prone. Roll a DC 15 constitution save. On failure, you take 2d6 damage and are knocked unconscious for 1 minute or until you receive damage from any source. On success, take half damage and you remain conscious.
Weapon Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Duelmaster Jorra, who famously tripped over his own weapon.

Weapon Attack.description: You lose your footing while attacking and slam your head into the ground.
Weapon Attack.effect: You fall prone, take 3d6 damage, and become unconscious for 1 minute or until you receive damage from any source.
Weapon Attack.lore: Even the great Velruun once shouted the wrong incantation at a critical moment.

Spell Attack.description: You are embarassed by your poor showing, but nothing remarkable happens.
Spell Attack.lore: Velruun’s misfortune in trying to fell into a decorative fountain while charging is still joked about today.

Spell Attack.description: You get wrapped up in your spellcasting and forget to watch your target.
Spell Attack.effect: Your target has advantage on their first attack roll against you next round.
Spell Attack.lore: Tales of Seer Halmin warn against lost his footing before a duel.

Spell Attack.description: You get wrapped up in your spellcasting and forget to watch your surroundings.
Spell Attack.effect: All enemies have advantage on their first attack roll against you next round.
Spell Attack.lore: Even the great Apprentice Threx once lost his footing before a duel.

Spell Attack.description: You are so wrapped up in your spellcasting that you forget you are fighting a battle.
Spell Attack.effect: All enemies have advantage on their attack rolls against you until the end of your next turn.
Spell Attack.lore: The archives of Silverdeep record a similar blunder during the Festival of Lights.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell creates a large plume of smoke obscuring your location.
Spell Attack.effect: The area in a 5-foot radius around your location becomes heavily obscured for 1 minute. A strong breeze can blow away the smoke in 1 round.
Spell Attack.lore: Legends from Stormwatch Keep speak of the day a hero fell into a decorative fountain while charging.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell misfires knocking you over.
Spell Attack.lore: The archives of Silverdeep record a similar blunder during the Battle of Shifting Sands.

Spell Attack.description: The spell fires in an unexpected manner, causing your confidence in your abilities to falter.
Spell Attack.effect: You have disadvantage on any spell attacks, and enemies have advantage against your spell savings throws until the end of your next turn.
Spell Attack.lore: The archives of The Mistlands record a similar blunder during the Festival of Lights.

Spell Attack.description: The placement of your spell startles your allies near your target, causing them to drop their guard.
Spell Attack.effect: Your target is able to use their reaction to take an attack of opportunity on one of your allies in melee range.
Spell Attack.lore: Bards sing mournfully of Apprentice Threx’s attempt to fell into a decorative fountain while charging.

Spell Attack.description: You scramble the ingredients of your component pouch or your focus becomes overloaded with magical energy and temporarily stops working.
Spell Attack.effect: You are unable to perform material components to cast spells until the end of your next turn.
Spell Attack.lore: Seer Halmin’s misfortune in trying to accidentally cast a spell on themselves is still joked about today.

Spell Attack.description: Your arm cramps as you cast.
Spell Attack.effect: You are unable to perform somatic components to cast spells until the end of your next turn.
Spell Attack.lore: Bards sing mournfully of Sir Galwyn’s attempt to shouted the wrong incantation at a critical moment.

Spell Attack.description: You bite your tongue as you cast.
Spell Attack.effect: You are unable to use verbal components to cast spells until the end of your next turn.
Spell Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Sir Galwyn, who famously froze mid-spell, overcome by sneezing.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell misfires and dazes you, causing you to lose track of the fight.
Spell Attack.effect: End your turn and move to the bottom of the initiative order at the start of the next round.
Spell Attack.lore: The archives of Ashvale record a similar blunder during the Great Summit.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell misfires causing you to panic.
Spell Attack.effect: End your current turn and you are surprised until the end of your next turn.
Spell Attack.lore: Legends from Bar Grunnd speak of the day a hero fell into a decorative fountain while charging.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell backfires creating a small explosion causing you to fall and bump your head.
Spell Attack.effect: You fall prone. Roll a DC 10 constitution save, on failure you take 1d6 bludeoning damage and are knocked unconscious for 1 minute or until you receive damage from any source. On success take half damage and you remain conscious.
Spell Attack.lore: The archives of Bar Grunnd record a similar blunder during the Siege of Broken Hill.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell backfires creating a large explosion causing you to fall and bump your head.
Spell Attack.effect: You fall prone. Roll a DC 15 constitution save, on failure you take 1d6 bludgeoning damage, 1d6 thunder damage, and are knocked unconscious for 1 minute or until you receive damage from any source. On success take half damage and you remain conscious.
Spell Attack.lore: Historians still tell the story of Apprentice Threx, who famously shouted the wrong incantation at a critical moment.

Spell Attack.description: Your spell completely backfires creating a large explosion causing you to fall and bump your head.
Spell Attack.effect: You hit yourself with your spell. If the spell effect is instant you take the full effect. If the spell requires concentration the effect persists until the end of your next turn. You also fall prone, take 1d6 bludgeoning damage, 1d6 thunder damage, and become unconscious for 1 minute or until you receive damage from any source.
Spell Attack.lore: The archives of Stormwatch Keep record a similar blunder during the Great Summit.

melee.effect: Your attack backfires and either through a parry, riposte, or defensive attack, the enemy reroutes your attack back at you, hitting a weak spot. The damage is doubled.
You miss the target entirely, leaving yourself open for an attack. The target of the attack must have a reaction available to make an attack.
You swing wildly, missing the target entirely, you instead hit your nearest ally within range, dealing normal damage. If no allies are within range, you instead drop your weapon.
Your bravado knows know bounds, you take a -2 to AC for 1d4 rounds.
You misstep, causing yourself to trip over your own feet. Roll a DEX Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you fall prone.
Your confidence and surety get the best of you, you take a -4 penalty to AC for one round.
A blunt strike makes a good connection with your head/helm, you are Stunned for one round.
For one reason or another, you become the target of the attack. Roll normal damage.
In the midst of battle, a spray of bodily fluid (blood, sweat, or tears) gets into your eyes, and you are blinded for one round.
It could be trauma, it could be a concussion, it could be anything, but you suddenly become confused for one round. Consult the Confusion Spell table for details.

You gave it your all, and it still wasn’t enough, you begin to feel extremely fatigued. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you become exhausted until the end of your next turn.
You swing with reckless abandon, striking your nearest ally. Target takes double damage and your next attack is with disadvantage.
Your swing becomes entangled in the fray and quite possibly your own pride or poor judgment. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you strike yourself, taking double damage.

All’s fair in love and war, right? Or not. The next melee attack against you strikes you in the groin, dealing an additional 1d6 damage. When/if this happens, roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you are knocked prone.
Should have stowed your shinies away better… you take 1d4 Slashing damage as your coin purse is damaged, spilling 10d4 coins onto the ground.

Your weapon strikes a solid point of contact on the enemy, they take no damage and a rattling vibration racks your grip. Roll a DEX Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you drop your weapon.
You enrage your target, dealing half damage and providing them a free attack, at Disadvantage. They must have a reaction available and this cannot result in a Fumble for the attacker.

Your swing is forceful and lethal, you meant every bit of strength (or finesse) behind this strike. Alas, you miss wildly. Roll a DEX Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you move 10 feet and fall prone. On a success you move 10 feet. Both outcomes incur an Attack of Opportunity.
Nothing additional happens. You miss. Congratulations on your failure! Task failed successfully.

You become enraged. After missing your intended target, you intend to make them the focal point of the rest of their life, or yours. All of your attacks must be directed towards the target of your failed attack. WIS Save ends this condition.

A spurt of blood or drop of sweat gets in your eye, causing your swings to be less effective. Your attacks must be made at disadvantage for the next 1d4 rounds, or until you use an action to wipe your eyes clean of the obstruction.
You have yet to get your land legs, apparently. Your movement speed becomes halved for the next 1d4 rounds as you lose your grip, footing, or focus in the midst of battle.

melee.description: Wah wah wah, wah wah wah!
melee.effect: It’s the classroom of the Peanuts gang, allegedly. Everything is garbled, muffled, or otherwise just unrecognizable. You become Deafened for the next 1d4 rounds as a loud noise or object causes you to temporarily lose your hearing.

Well that wasn’t supposed to happen! You slam your hand in between the handle of your weapon and a hard surface, maybe a wall or the enemy’s armor. Roll a DEX Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you take 1d4 bludgeoning damage and drop your weapon.
You lose your grip or footing and become easier to hit for 1d4 rounds, giving all melee attackers advantage against you.
You’re quite motivated by the flourish or technique you have just exhibited. Driven by this execution, you gain a +1 Bonus to all Attack rolls for the next 1d6 rounds.
Your turn ends.

Your grip becomes ineffective and so does your strike. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you sustain a hairline fracture in your weapon hand and all attacks are made at Disadvantage until you have taken a Long Rest or undergo Magical Healing.
You cannot, for the life of you, focus the way you are used to. For the next 1d4 Rounds you must subtract 1d4 from all of your Attack Rolls, effectively suffering from the effects of the Bane Spell.
For the next 1d4 rounds, the intended target of this attack can re-roll any d20 rolls against you that result in a 1 or 2 on the die.

Hey! Free Room! No, wait… wrong lodging. Your weapon becomes lodged into the nearest object and as a result becomes stuck. You must pass a successful STR Check, DC equivalent to the intended target’s AC.
You open yourself up for an attack, a deadly one. If the intended target of this attack has a Reaction available, they may make one Attack of Opportunity against you with Advantage.

Worst case scenario plays out before your eyes, but you have a single last-second calculation you can make to avoid severe error. Make a DEX/WIS Saving Throw against the  intended target’s AC, on a failure if your weapon is non-magical, it breaks beyond repair.
Whoopsie. You heave your weapon with spectacular fashion as it leaves your hand and flies harmlessly through the air, 20 feet from your position in a random direction (DM’s discretion).
Nothing happens. Nice.

Maybe it’s something in the target’s eye, maybe they remind you of a pitiful person you read about, either way, there is a flicker of pity in you against the target. For the remainder of the encounter, all Attack Rolls against the target are made with a -2 penalty.
If the intended target of this attack has a Reaction available, they may take the Disengage Action
If the intended target of this attack has a Reaction available, they may take the Dodge Action.
You become caught up in the melee, perhaps it’s analysis paralysis, regardless of the reasoning… you forego your next turn.
You lose the ability to hit 100%, if only briefly. Your next successful Attack Roll deals only half damage.

Whether through sheer pity, fatigue, or just an inability to focus, your ability to deal regular damage becomes hampered. For the rest of the encounter, all damage done to the intended target of this attack by you, is reduced by 2 points (minimum of 1).

The fight is taking its toll on you, or maybe you’re just having a rough day. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail you become incapacitated for the next 1d4 rounds. You may make a CON Save on each of your turns to end this effect.
If the intended target of this attack has a Reaction available, they may use the Shove action against you, uncontested.
Your intended target takes ire against you in this moment. If their next Attack Roll hits you, it becomes a Critical Hit. If the Attack Roll is a Natural 20, they deal Triple Damage.

You feel compelled to destroy the target of this attack. Your fury is insatiable. For the next 1d4 rounds you feel compelled to attack only this target. This effect ends early if the target dies. These Attack Rolls are made at Disadvantage.

Whether fear or frustration, you become forced into Fight or Flight mode. For the next 1d4 rounds you are unable to distinguish friend from foe. This condition ends early if another creature uses an Action to shake you out of it.

Your ability to stay focused on what matters most becomes muddled as you try to concentrate on the fight in front of you. Roll a WIS Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail you subtract 1d4 from all of your Saving Throws for the next 1d4 rounds.

You pull a muscle, succumb to cramping, or are otherwise hampered in your ability to carry through your focus and damage. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail your Strength Score is reduced by 2 until the end of the encounter.

Your footing becomes clumsy, the environment is hazardous, or perhaps you are a bit fatigued. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail your Dexterity Score is reduced by 2 until the end of the encounter.

You’re focused, maybe too focused, your perception of the world around you becomes a bit foggy, and your street smarts become hazy. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail your Wisdom Score is reduced by 2 until the end of the encounter.
The Natural 1 is treated as a regular roll. If the numerical value of the Attack Roll would hit the intended target, it deals half damage.

ranged.effect: Something with you bow/crossbow snaps, effectively rendering your weapon useless in a ranged capability. You can fix your weapon and restore it back to working order with 10 minutes of continuous and uninterrupted downtime.

ranged.description: I used to be an Adventurer like you…
ranged.effect: Well… you know how it goes… you deal double damage to yourself and knock yourself Prone. Hopefully you aren’t stuck doing guard duty while your cousin gets to go out fighting dragons.
You knock your arrow/bolt incorrectly, it goes wide, striking the furthest creature from where the projectile was fired (friend or foe) dealing normal damage.
Your weapon fires! But where is the satisfying *thunk* of a well-placed shot? Well, that’s the thing... it isn’t a well-placed shot. No one knows where the projectile ended up. It’s gone as Hell.
Either karma dislikes your last snarky remark, or you’ve tempted luck and taunted fate too far. For the next 1d4 rounds, all of your attacks must be made with Disadvantage.
Your projectile’s trajectory goes awry and you strike the nearest friendly combatant to your current location, regardless of the weapon’s range increments. The attack deals normal damage.

Your projectile either explodes into splinters or breaks apart before it has a chance to do any harm. In addition, Roll a Dexterity Saving Throw, on a failure you take 1d6 piercing damage from the fallout.

Either your water intake is too low, you’re suffering from a potassium deficit, or you didn’t warm up before the fight! In any case, you are unable to make any ranged attacks until you use an Action to resolve the cramping in your hand or arm.

Well… at least you didn’t shoot yourself in the knee! Your finger or hand slips and you strike yourself in the leg by accident. The attack deals normal damage and your movement speed is halved until you move the full extent of your normal movement cumulatively.
You pull the bowstring back too close to your cheek and it clips you with a painful swipe, you take 1d4 slashing damage and have Disadvantage on all attack rolls until the end of your next turn.

Maybe it’s because you missed, maybe it’s personal, regardless… you are sighted in on a single target. For the next 1d4 rounds, you must make all your attacks against the target of this Fumble at Disadvantage.

Either the lighting is bad or a cloud of dirt has kicked up and hindered your ability to make an effective shot. All your shots must be made with Disadvantage until you move at least half your movement speed in a straight line, from your current location.

Maybe it’s blood, maybe it’s sweat, something springs back towards you off of your bowstring and gets into your eyes. You are Blinded for the next 1d4 rounds. Alternatively, you can use an Action to end this condition by clearing your eyes.

Maybe it’s the adrenaline coursing through your veins, maybe your palms are sweaty, knees weak, arms are heavy… Anyway… you fumble with your ammunition and are unable to make attacks with your ranged weapon until the end of your next turn.
You continue to fire at your target until the end of your next turn. This is done at Disadvantage.

The target of your attack is not happy with you and is rather displeased with your poor performance... or maybe they just don’t like you. Maybe it’s both. Regardless, the next attack they make against you is done at Advantage.

ranged.description: Uh… next one is on me!
ranged.effect: Well… that wasn’t supposed to happen… Your shot strikes a fellow friendly creature and shatters a consumable, destroying it. If they are carrying more than one, the targeted item of this fumble is determined at random. If they have none, this deals normal damage.

Your shot misses so beautifully that you dislodge an object above you (if feasible). Roll a DEX Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail you sustain 2d6 damage with a type of the DM’s choosing (i.e., bludgeoning, piercing, slashing, fire, poison, etc.).

Nice and steady. You got this. Flawless execution… except this time. You fumble hard and knock all of your ammunition onto the ground at your feet. You must spend an Action to re-slot your ammunition before making another ranged attack.

Your shot goes wild and you strike a fellow friendly creature right in the coin purse. The good news is, it isn’t the one they had at birth. The bad news is they must spend one minute picking up all of their currency and another minute to repair their coin purse.

ranged.description: I swear it was an accident…
ranged.effect: Your shot zips by a friendly combatants head and they take notice, eyeing you cautiously. Their next attack is made with Disadvantage.
Your projectile goes wide and strikes the furthest friendly combatant from your current location, regardless of the weapon’s range increment. Whoops!

Your shot misses the target entirely and strikes a creature of the DM’s choosing. This can be done by choice or a dice roll. If the target is a hostile creature, deal normal damage. If the target is a friendly creature, deal double damage.
You’re better than that… it wasn’t your best moment and you feel foolish for it. All of your attacks must be made at Disadvantage until you land a successful hit on a target.
Your footing betrays you as you pay no mind to your environment in this moment and misstep. Luckily, you have not rolled your ankle, unluckily enough though… you have fallen prone.

You swear that’s the target, right there, in the distance. Until the end of your next turn you are completely convinced that the furthest friendly combatant to your current location is an enemy target. This creature becomes the focus of your attacks.

Your footing or aim goes completely awry and you fire your arrow/bolt directly downward… into your foot and dealing normal damage. Roll a DEX Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure your movement becomes 0 until you use an action to remove the projectile.
You forget Archery 101 and pull a n00b mistake. You catch your ear in the release of the string and take 1d4 slashing damage and are deafened until the end of your next turn.

Tunnel vision sets in. You are focused. You sight in. Your vision vignettes. But wait, that’s not laser-focus, that’s a lack of oxygen. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a failure you gain one level of Exhaustion.

Your inability to strike the foe is nigh hilarious, to the point where it is actually laughable, and even inspirational. All hostile creatures within 10 feet of the intended target gains 1d4 to their Attack Rolls until the end of your next turn.
Wait… what, no. Hold on. You just, I… they… hold on. You sight in to the point of tunnel vision and become a tad bit caught up and disoriented. You are stunned until the end of your next turn.
Your turn ends.
You cannot, for the life of you, focus the way you are used to. For the next 1d4 Rounds you must subtract 1d4 from all of your Attack Rolls, effectively suffering from the effects of the Bane Spell.
For the next 1d4 rounds, the intended target of this attack can re-roll any d20 rolls against you that result in a 1 or 2 on the die.
Nothing happens. Nice.

You fire and… well, that… that’s not an arrow/bolt, that is… that’s your weapon. How? We don’t know. No one does. It’s a beautiful disaster. Hilariously poetic. You should be proud. How did you do that? Your weapon flies 10 feet towards the target, dealing no damage.

ranged.description: Yeah, That’s Right… You Better Run!
ranged.effect: If the intended target of this attack has a Reaction available, they may take the Disengage Action (or Dash Action).
If the intended target of this attack has a Reaction available, they may take the Dodge Action.
You become caught up in the moment, perhaps it’s analysis paralysis, regardless of the reasoning… you forego your next turn.
You lose the ability to hit 100%, if only briefly. Your next successful Attack Roll deals only half damage.

Whether through sheer pity, fatigue, or just an inability to focus, your ability to deal regular damage becomes hampered. For the rest of the encounter, all damage done to the intended target of this attack by you, is reduced by 2 points (minimum of 1).

The fight is taking its toll on you, or maybe you’re just having a rough day. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail you become incapacitated for the next 1d4 rounds. You may make a CON Save on each of your turns to end this effect.

A glint of light off of the target’s armor or weapon reflects the light just right and it strikes you in the cornea long enough to have an effect. All of your Attack Rolls are made at disadvantage until the end of your next turn.
Your intended target takes ire against you in this moment. If their next Attack Roll hits you, it becomes a Critical Hit. If the Attack Roll is a Natural 20, they deal Triple Damage.

Whether fear or frustration, you become forced into Fight or Flight mode. For the next 1d4 rounds you are unable to distinguish friend from foe. This condition ends early if another creature uses an Action to shake you out of it.

Your ability to stay focused on what matters most becomes muddled as you try to concentrate on the fight in front of you. Roll a WIS Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail you subtract 1d4 from all of your Saving Throws for the next 1d4 rounds.
Your shot goes very awry and strikes a nearby animal (or a creature with the Beast type) and it immediately enters the fray. It then rolls its initiative and resumes its turns as normal.

You pull a muscle, succumb to cramping, or are otherwise hampered in your ability to carry through your focus and damage. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail your Strength Score is reduced by 2 until the end of the encounter.

Your footing becomes clumsy, the environment is hazardous, or perhaps you are a bit fatigued. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail your Dexterity Score is reduced by 2 until the end of the encounter.

You’re focused, maybe too focused, your perception of the world around you becomes a bit foggy, and your street smarts become hazy. Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC, on a fail your Wisdom Score is reduced by 2 until the end of the encounter.
The Natural 1 is treated as a regular roll. If the numerical value of the Attack Roll would hit the intended target, it deals half damage.

magic.effect: Your intention to make use of the weave to cast magic has catastrophically backfired. An extraplanar creature with a CR equal to the spell’s level or lower is brought forth into the fray. The creature is hostile toward all combatants and takes its turn after yours.

The weave backfires on you in this moment, causing arcane energy to explode. All creatures within 10 feet of you take Xd4 force damage, including yourself, as a wild magic surge erupts. X = Spell Level.

Your connection to the magics that surround you have become taxing. In this moment, you succumb to the arcane powers that surround you. Roll a WIS Save (DC = Target’s AC), on a fail, you take Xd6 Psychic damage. X = Level of the spell cast.
Focusing your mental acuity on the magics around you can take its toll. Roll a WIS Save (DC = Target’s AC), on a fail you become Stunned for 1d4 rounds.
The magics that surround us are wild! Your spell goes wild and soars into the nearest friendly combatant, dealing normal damage.
You’re heavily focused on what you are doing, which is great, what isn’t great is that you have misplaced your footing and fallen prone. Whoops.

magic.description: I cast Fireball! No, wait… no I don’t!
magic.effect: The cliché! The legend! The arson! Your magics betray you in this moment and an eruption of fire explodes, centered on your location, affecting all targets similarly as if you had casted Fireball on your square. Luckily, the damage is 4d6 as opposed to 8d6.

magic.description: You get a missile! You get a missile!
magic.effect: Your ability to focus the powers of magic manifest themselves in the form of wild and uncontrollable motes of Force. Three Magic Missiles strike three target’s at random, dealing 1d4 Force damage on a hit. DM’s discretion.

Channeling magic is hard, there’s no question about it, it can exhaust one’s mind and cause… side effects. Roll a WIS Save (DC = Target’s AC). On a failure, you become Confused for the next 1d4 rounds. Consult the Confusion Spell table for details.

You’re focus on downing the enemy manifests as pure hatred… hatred without aim… All targets within 15 feet of you (including yourself) take 1d12 necrotic damage as a pulse of dark energy emits from you in a flash of arcane bewilderment.

magic.description: Only You Can Prevent Force Fires
magic.effect: Your spell sails wide and strikes a nearby object, possibly creating an environmental hazard at your expense. This is determined by the DM and can be anywhere from a raging forest fire to nothing at all. Hopefully they aren’t out for blood!

magic.description: I swear that was an accident…
magic.effect: Great news, the spell fires off without a hitch! Bad news, it strikes the wrong target… in fact, it strikes one of your party members! This is determined by the DM, either by choice or at random via a dice roll.

The magics that you have become reliant upon are not as potent and impactful as they once were. For the next 1d4 rounds any damaging/healing spells you cast deal half the amount of damage or only heal half as much (minimum of 1).

The spells you have become used to are… different. The elemental nature of what you have studied has shifted and becomes unreliable. For the next 1d4 rounds your spells may cause a different type of damage. DM’s discretion.

Your ability to conjure up magic to do your bidding and apply it in the format you wished for does not work. Instead, a random object or small animal pops into existence 10 feet away from you. This object/creature is harmless and is not hostile to any combatant.

Your spell does not do what you intended… at all. Instead, your DM modifies the spell’s nature by changing a single letter of their choosing in the name of the Spell. If a result cannot be reached within a reasonable amount of time, nothing happens.
A wave of Evocation magic washes over your target, though the application may not be what you intended. You heal the target for 1d8 points of healing.
All that you see, absolute horror. The magics used in the casting of the spell are turned inward and cause a severe backlash at you. You become blinded for the next 1d4 rounds.

Well, something is certainly wrong. Either a complete brain fart, a disruption in your connectivity to your source of magic, or something else entirely. Until the end of your next turn you are unable to use any magic or previously existing spells you are concentrating on.
Your turn ends.

Get the big one, or the goons, maybe the furthest one, wait… isn’t there only one target? You are overcome with analysis paralysis and with the arcane magics to boot, you are caught up in it. You become Paralyzed until the start of your next turn.

Mental health is just as important as physiological health, you know. You have overworked yourself and as a result, succumb to the nature of phantasmagoria. You are Frightened until the end of your next turn. Treat the target of this spell as the source of your fear.

Maybe it’s time to settle this the ol’ fashioned way, with words. Carefully selected words and a stern talking to. You forego the spell and instead hurl a hurtful phrase at the target with some choice words and a firm stance. Go get ‘em, tiger.

Your meddling in the ability to put your mind to work has strained it to the point of temporary befuddlement. Your ability to communicate becomes hampered and you speak an unintelligible conglomerate of gibberish for the next 1d4 rounds.

magic.description: Sure, beat up on the smart one…
magic.effect: Your focus on casting has distracted you and your enemy sees an opening. All attacks made against you are at Advantage until the start of your next turn.

Your spell backfires, striking your mind. You become dazed and confused as you try to recollect your thoughts. For the next 1d4 rounds, you are unable to speak intelligibly and cannot cast spells that use the Verbal component.

The magical energies which concoct the spells from within you are otherwise channeled downwards. You sprout roots from your feet which hold you in place, reducing your speed to 0 feet. You must use an action to remove the roots.
Your ire is cold, maybe too cold. The spell is lost in the casting and you take half its damage in cold damage.

magic.description: Everything Is Fine, This Is Fine
magic.effect: Roll a DEX Save, on a fail you immolate, taking your proficiency bonus in d6’s of fire damage. On a success you sustain only half damage.

The raw and violent nature of the weave take a strong amount of focus and concentration, so much so that it takes its toll on you. You sustain Psychic damage in d6’s equivalent to Spell Slot that was lost in the casting.

Revved up like a deuce in the middle of the night, you are fired up, but maybe too much. The magics are not channeled correctly and in the spell’s faltering nature, your struck with half of the spell’s damage in radiant damage.

The virulent and volatile nature of magic during the spell’s casting is affected by the elemental planes. It backfires violently, coating you and all creatures within 5 feet of you in acidic ire, sustaining 4d4 acid damage.

Your cruel, device. Your blood, like ice. One cast, could kill. The pain, the thrill. Unfortunately no one named Alice is here to rock this moment with a ballad, but rather the magics implode and reinstate themselves as a poisonous ichor which explode in your face, causing you 3d6 poison damage.

In an attempt to cause death, it instead turns against you. Roll a CON Save against the target’s AC. On a failure, you sustain one of two effects: 4d6 necrotic damage, or 2d6 necrotic damage and 1 Death Saving Throw Fail.
Nothing happens. Nice.
Maybe it’s the light, maybe its their charisma, maybe its Maybelline, nobody knows. But the intended target of this spell becomes an ally in your eyes for the next 1d4 rounds.

The spell fails in a spectacularly beautiful display of fireworks, unfortunately this means you become deafened for the next 1d4 rounds and must make all spell attacks at disadvantage that use the Verbal component

What you do with the weave is beautiful, deadly, and even mysterious. Your body is a conduit for what you do with the magic you have access to, only this time… things do not go as planned. You sustain one level of Exhaustion.

In an attempt to overpower your enemy, it seems as though this attempt turns 180 degrees on you as you become frightened of the intended target of this Spell for the next 1d4 rounds. A successful WIS Save against the target’s  AC may be attempted at the end of all subsequent turns to end the effect.
Roll a CON Save against the intended target’s AC. On a fail, you are incapacitated for the next 1d4 rounds, or until someone uses an action to stir you. On a success nothing additional happens.

They were there a second ago! Where did they go?! You have inadvertently caused the target of this spell to go invisible until the end of your next turn, or until they make any hostile/offensive actions, as per the Invisibility Spell.
Hopefully the combatants have chosen against engaging in combat with you after this. You are struck with a feeling of rigor mortis as you succumb to paralysis until the end of your next turn.

Roll a CON Save equivalent to the target’s AC. On a fail you are immediately petrified as the magics used in the spell’s casting begin to solidify across your form. This gradually ends after 1d6 hours or the use of Greater Restoration or equivalent.

Your ability to focus on any one thing becomes sporadic and rogue-like, causing you to lose touch with your focus. For the next 1d4 rounds you have disadvantage on all attack rolls and CON Saving Throws made to maintain concentration on spells.
You are momentarily stricken with a blast of paralysis and fall prone where you stand. If you are climbing or otherwise hanging onto a ledge, ladder, or other object, you fall.

Grasping vines, roots, or other earthen material creep up from the ground and hold you in place, forcing you into the Restrained condition. This can be ended when you or another creature use an action to remove the restraining objects from your body.
Your spell backfires, staggering you 5 feet in a random direction. You sustain 1d4 Force damage and become Stunned until the end of your next turn.
Roll a CON Saving Throw against the intended target’s AC, on a fail you fall unconscious. This condition ends when you sustain damage or a creature uses and Action to stir you.
The blast of magic used in the spell’s casting is disrupted and you are forced 10 feet backwards violently and fall prone, sustaining 1d6 bludgeoning damage.

Roll a WIS Save against the intended target’s AC. On a fail, you lose an additional Spell Slot, equivalent to the level used in the Spell’s casting. If none are available, the next threshold lower is consumed, instead. If there are none available, nothing additional happens.
The Natural 1 is treated as a regular roll. If the numerical value of the Attack Roll would hit the intended target, it deals half damage.
